/lit/ is for the discussion of literature, specifically books (fiction & non-fiction), short stories, poetry, creative writing, etc. If you want to discuss history, religion, or the humanities, go to /his/. If you want to discuss politics, go to /pol/. Philosophical discussion can go on either /lit/ or /his/, but those discussions of philosophy that take place on /lit/ should be based around specific philosophical works to which posters can refer.

Check the wiki, the catalog, and the archive before asking for advice or recommendations, and please refrain from starting new threads for questions that can be answered by a search engine.

/lit/ is a slow board! Please take the time to read what others have written, and try to make thoughtful, well-written posts of your own. Bump replies are not necessary.

>>21431886
>What we have been saying can all be summed up in the judgment which Jesus passes with intolerable clarity: "Say, ‘We are unworthy servants.’" But we should isolate two different elements in this saying in Luke 17:10. Jesus says: "When you have done all that is commanded. . . ." Jesus is not evading the problem of law and order. There is a divine law, which is a commandment, and which is addressed to us. Hence we have to fulfill it to the letter. We have to do all that is commanded. The sense or conviction of the utter futility of the work we do must not prevent us from doing it. The judgment of uselessness is no excuse for inaction. It is not before doing or praying or preaching that we are to proclaim their inutility. It is not before their work that Elisha, Jehu, and Hezekiah proclaim the uselessness of their work, which is only a fulfillment of God’s action. Pronounced in advance, futility becomes justification of scorn of God and his word and work. It is after doing what is commanded, when everything has been done in the sphere of human decisions and means, when in terms of the relation to God every effort has been made to know the will of God and to obey it, when in the arena of life there has been full acceptance of all responsibilities and interpretations and commitments and conflicts, it is then and only then that the judgment takes on meaning: all this (that we had to do) is useless; all this we cast from us to put it in thy hands, O Lord; all this belongs no more to the human order but to the order of thy kingdom. Thou mayest use this or that work to build up the kingdom thou art preparing. In thy liberty thou mayest make as barren as the fig-tree any of the works which we have undertaken to thy glory. This is no longer our concern. It is no longer in our hands. What belonged to our sphere we have done. Now, 0 Lord, we may set it aside, having done all that was commanded. This is how Elisha and Elijah finished their course.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>21432182
>The second point to be noted in the verse is that it is not God or Jesus who passes the verdict of inutility. It is we ourselves who must pronounce it on our work: "We are unprofitable servants." God does not judge us thus. He does not reject either us or our works. Or rather, he does not echo the verdict if we have passed it ourselves. If (as Christ demands) we judge ourselves in this way when we have done all we could do and accepted all our responsibilities, if we are able to view our own works and most enthusiastic enterprises with the distance and detachment and humor that enable us to pronounce them useless, then we may be assured of hearing God say: "Well done, good and faithful servant" (Matthew 25:21). But if we pass in advance this bitter judgment of uselessness that paralyzes and discourages us, if we are thus completely lacking in love for God, or if on the other hand we magnify our works and regard them as important and successful (Jesus, little Jesus, I have so wonderfully exalted you, but if I had attacked you in your defenselessness your shame would have been as great as your glory. . . .), if we come before God decked out in the glory of these lofty, grandiose, and successful works, then . . . "Woe to you that are rich" (Luke 6:24), for the rich man today is the successful man. Everything is useless, and we are thus tempted to add: Everything, then, is vanity. We are tempted, for it is a temptation to do only what is useful and to assimilate the judgment of Ecclesiastes on vanity (1:2ff.) to the inutility which we have been briefly sketching. Now this spontaneous reaction raises a question. Why are we so concerned about utility? Why do we regard what is not useful as worthless? In reality, we are obsessed at this point by the views of our age and century and technology. Everything has to serve some purpose. If it does not, it is not worth doing. And when we talk in this way we are not governed by a desire to serve but by visions of what is great and powerful and effective. We are driven by the utility of the world and the importance of results. What counts is what may be seen, achievement, victory, whether it be over hunger or a political foe or what have you. What matters is that it be useful.

Great passages. Thank you for sharing them in my bait thread. I was frustrated with the inability to find the the crux of Ellul's Christianity.
>Now this spontaneous reaction raises a question. Why are we so concerned about utility? Why do we regard what is not useful as worthless? In reality, we are obsessed at this point by the views of our age and century and technology. Everything has to serve some purpose. If it does not, it is not worth doing. And when we talk in this way we are not governed by a desire to serve but by visions of what is great and powerful and effective. We are driven by the utility of the world and the importance of results. What counts is what may be seen, achievement, victory, whether it be over hunger or a political foe or what have you. What matters is that it be useful.
This quote dovetails well with Ellul's interpretation of the Garden of Eden myth in Freedom, Love, and Power. As Ellul explains, humanity was once directed to tend to the garden for no apparent reason. Mankind rebelled by consuming the fruit that allowed us to judge, to leave the protection of God and supply those reasons for ourselves, and now we have no choice but to be enslaved to the necessity of work. And, in this way, faith in Christ's sacrifice is a way of abdicating this responsibility back to God and returning to the "purposeless" freedom found in the Garden of Eden. I can see why Ellul loves Ecclesiastes so much as well. Zooming out further, now we understand the soteriological context behind Ellul's analysis of technique—the technological society threatens to annihilate every vestige of the possibility of a Christian life.

I still find it difficult to square Ellul's complete disregard of morality, as I see it more as an exaggeration or maybe a way of subordinating morality to God, highlighting the "double morality" of the world vs. the impossible standard of the divine, but I can see where he's coming from if we mean coming to grasp with the limitations of man's perspective.

From the account of Genesis in Ellul's Freedom, Love, and Power.
>The second aspect of freedom comes from verses 16 and 17, which deal with the commandment: ‘You may eat from every tree in the garden, but not from the tree that permits the discernment of good and evil; for on the day you eat from it, you have died.’ For many, this text is proof that God is not good because he imposed this interdiction. I would like to go back to what we discussed earlier, namely, the matter of declaring good and evil by saying: This is good and that is bad. What this really means is to put oneself in the place of God. Only God speaks the good. Either you say what God says or you say something else, and that is a problem. Putting yourself in God’s place inevitably involves breaking the relationship with him; and since he is the living one (the totality of all being), any claim of replacing him involves cutting oneself off from life, which results in death. The text is commonly translated as: On (or from) the day you eat of it, you will die. However, the Hebrew text is in the imperfect tense; consequently, the future tense should not be used. It is not at all a punishment or penalty that is imposed. What the text is literally saying is that from the very day you ate of it you would be dead. It is not that you will die sometime in the future. What this means is that from the very moment you would wish to decree what is good and what is evil, it would mean that you are already dead. It is not a matter of a punishment, but of a process of breaking off with God by no longer listening to him, putting yourself in his place, from then on saying by yourself what is good and evil in his place; and you have begun to be dead. At this point, living in freedom is impossible.
>The situation is analogous to one in which a parent warns a child not to touch a hot stove because she will burn her hand. Burning her hand is not a punishment. There is only a punishment if the parent says: If you try to touch the stove, you must go to your room. The parent warns the child of the reality: to touch something hot is to burn your hand. We have hopelessly confused God’s warnings with commandments. In the entire Old Testament, God only warns his people of what will happen if they do this or that.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>21432639
>What our text reveals, therefore, is that the freedom of humanity exists only if they remain in communion with God, this communion being a relationship of love. All along we have seen the importance of love and sexual communion and so on, and all this is directed at the relationship of love between God and humanity, even in the most physical sense. Hence, what is commonly understood as a commandment is not at all a law imposed on humanity; it is not an imperative, a constraint, or something negative, but a condition for being alive. Humanity is told that in order to continue to live, it is not enough to eat from the tree of life, but you must remain in your relationship with God and receive the spirit, the spirit that comes and goes as an element of freedom; and because of this, you cannot claim the right of deciding what is good and evil in God’s place, instead of listening to the Word of God. It is the very condition of freedom, because God reserves for humanity the possibility to do otherwise.
>Next comes the question of service. In the fifteenth verse we read that Yahweh takes humanity and puts them in the garden of Eden to work it and to keep it. It is rather amusing that many commentaries say something to the effect that this is ridiculous. Why work in a garden when it has already been explained that the soil produced all kinds of fruit by itself? Why did the garden have to be guarded? Father Chaine, in his commentary, concludes that the writer had a bad day and even a lapse of memory. I think, on the contrary, that this text is full of meaning.
>Humanity is called to render a service, but one that is useless. Of course, the garden did not need to be cultivated since it was fruitful, and it did not need to be guarded since there were no external enemies. This is exactly the point: there is no necessity to work and there is no necessity to be productive. All there is, is the Word of God. God tells humanity that they are there to cultivate and keep the garden. What humanity is therefore faced with is: ‘God says that I should do this, it serves no purpose, but I will do it.’ What God says is the good. If, on the other hand, humanity begins to say, ‘Of what use is it?’ that is like the tree of knowledge of good and evil. ‘Since the garden doesn’t require cultivation, I do not need to work, and since there are no enemies, I do not need to guard it, so I won’t do it.’ That is the evil. This response may be morally legitimate: ‘Since it serves no purpose, I will not do it.’ But God said: ‘Do it’; and that is the trouble, to have confidence or not in the Word of God. This is the situation humanity had to face. In any case, it is clear that it is impossible to derive from these well-known texts the law of work. Work as such does not exist for humanity as a law of creation.

>>21432643
>That this text isn’t about real work is confirmed by the use of the Hebrew word used for working the garden, namely, avoda, which means worship. In other words: ‘You will worship God through working and guarding it, knowing very well that these actions are unnecessary; but it is simply a form of worship, and you honour and adore him by it. It is not in order to produce, but to honour in reciprocity.’ All the early Jewish commentaries have strongly suggested that what this means is that God did not create humanity for nothing. He did not launch humanity into an emptiness. Humanity has a role to play. Leisure is not a life, and empty leisure is not good. This role, according to the Hebrew word avoda, is to bring the whole of the garden of Eden before God so that all of creation will adore God through this human service. When humanity serves God for nothing and without an objective, they bring the creation to worship God.
>The above, I believe, is the meaning of verses 15 to 17. We begin to see where the story of good and evil comes from. Humanity could refuse to work, but this has consequences that we will soon examine. **The refusal to work for nothing led to the necessity of having to work for something. There no longer was any choice.**

>>21431745
Overall, I found nothing unique in Wolfe. Perhaps it's because I've read quite a bit of odd fantasy; if all I read was mainstream stuff, then I'd surely find Wolfe unpredictable, since he is a step above them. But compared to Leiber, Howard, Dunsany, Eddison, Kipling, Haggard, Peake, Mieville, or Moorcock, Wolfe is nothing special.

Perhaps I just got my hopes up too high. I imagined something that might evoke Peake or Leiber (at his best), perhaps with a complexity and depth gesturing toward Milton or Ariosto. I could hardly imagine a better book than that, but even a book half that good would be a delight--or a book that was nothing like that, but was unpredictable and seductive in some other way.

I kept waiting for something to happen, but it never really did. It all plods along without much rise or fall, just the constant moving action to make us think something interesting is happening. I did find some promise, some moments that I would have loved to see the author explore, particularly those odd moments where Silver Age Sci Fi crept in, but each time he touched upon these, he would return immediately to the smallness of his plot and his annoying prick of a narrator. I never found the book to be difficult or complex, merely tiring. the unusual parts were evasive and vague, and the dull parts constant and repetitive.

The whole structure (or lack of it) does leave things up to interpretation, and perhaps that's what some readers find appealing: that they can superimpose their own thoughts and values onto the narrator, and onto the plot itself. But at that point, they don't like the book Wolfe wrote, they like the book they are writing between his lines.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>21431745
>>21431758
Then there is the fact that every character you meet in the story turns up again, hundreds of miles away, to reveal that they are someone else and have been secretly controlling the action of the plot. It feels like the entire world is populated by about fifteen people who follow the narrator around wherever he goes. If the next two books continue along the same lines, then the big reveal will be that the world is entirely populated by no more than three superpowered shapeshifters.

Everyone in the book has secret identities, secret connections to grand conspiracies, and important plot elements that they conveniently hide until the last minute, only doling out clues here and there. There are no normal people in this world, only double agents and kings in disguise. Every analysis I've read of this book mentions that even the narrator is unreliable.

This can be an effective technique, but in combination with a world of infinite, unpredictable intrigue, Wolfe's story begins to evoke something between a soap opera and a convoluted mystery novel, relying on impossible and contradictory scenarios to mislead the audience. Apparently, this is the thing his fans most appreciate about him--I find it to be an insulting and artificial game.

I agree with this reviewer that there is simply not enough structure to the story to make the narrator's unreliability meaningful. In order for unreliable narration to be effective, there must be some clear and evident counter-story that undermines it. Without that, it is not possible to determine meaning, because there's nowhere to start: everything is equally shaky.

At that point, it's just a trick--adding complexity to the surface of the story without actually producing any new meaning. I know most sci fi and fantasy authors seem to love complexity for its own sake, but it's a cardinal sin of storytelling: don't add something into your story unless it needs to be there. Covering the story with a lot of vagaries and noise may impress some, but won't stand up to careful reading.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>21434053
It's conservation of detail. You don't want to have too much that isn't important to the core narrative of your book, because you're effectively muddying the waters. The Sam and Frodo password stuff serves its purpose as a character moment, rather than as set-up, so it's still relevant to the narrative. You can briefly touch upon irrelevant topics, but going into them when they're not relevant can often seem pointless. People don't care about what's not important to the book. That said there's absolutely room for unnecessary stuff, but if you're gonna have that, you may as well have it be important in other ways (characterisation and the like).

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Title: A Lady of Rooksgrave Manor
Author: Kathryn Moon
Rating: 4/10


[Plot]
The premise of the book is simple - a young and pretty maid in victorian London(?) is a wicked, lustful girl, fucking and ruting with pretty boys at every opportunity, which cost her multiple jobs. Eventually, a tall and handsome doctor with broad shoulders invites her to his office for obvious reasons, where they immediately fuck. However, in the middle of the coitus the man turns into a big monster. She doesn't mind much, which leads for her being invited to work in a Rooksgrave Manor, place where adventurous young women 'service' monster men.

[Review]
This book is almost exclusively porn. Seriously, there is very little plot, if at all. Majority of it is just the main character being fucked in different positions or combination of partners. Despite how well-written the book is (on a technical level), it did raise my opinion of typical male Harem Erotica. In a typical male erotica book the protagonist has adventure, rivarly, fights for what he believes, etc. Fucking is an addition to that, the girls have to be given at least symbolic courting. In this book the protagonist is wanted and desired from the get-go.

Female sexuality is different from male, that is obvious for everyone with three brain cells. However, the protagonist in this book has no real character traits or personality aside of being a whore. Her character starts and ends with wanting to fuck handsome men, multiple at times, especially monster men. There is nothing more to say about her. Every handsome, powerful man metaphorically falls to his knees in front of her due to her being so fuckable; it's not even about beauty, I don't think the author called the protagonist beautiful or pretty even once. Still, she is extremely desired by everyone, all men care about is spoiling her and talking how her constant urge to fuck makes her special.

This might be the most radical Female Fantasy you will ever read - woman just has to exist and want to fuck, and everyone calls her queen and love of their life. Maybe it's because lately I've taken significant amount of mental damage due to loneliness and going into the Blackpill rabbithole, but reading this book literally drained life from me. There are male equivalents of this book, but they are extremely niche. Meanwhile this is the most popular female erotica book I've seen.

4/10

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>21434537
Beyond moving to a country that primarily speaks it, consistently consuming TV shows/movies/books (no English subtitles) in the language, writing down the phrases/words you see often and don't know yet, then drilling yourself on Anki.

This is pretty much the only way to become truly fluent and this will still take years. Duolingo or similar apps can help with grammar rules/practice but these should be used as supplements.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>21434537
Immersion. Which usually is where you fail, even in language learning classes, because people don't take it seriously enough to actually remain immersed in said language. It's only by choosing to constantly listen to media in the language, to speak with natives, ideally to be among natives in a country where it's the native tongue, that you will make the most progress.
Secondarily it's about learning style. Some people are very good at absorbing systematic learning, repeating verb forms, practicing nouns with flip cards; others don't progress at all that way and instead do much better the language bum way, by improvising and doing things wrong but over time getting an "ear" for what's correct and what isn't, and learning words organically through exposure. Again the school or class environment really shafts the second learning type there.

As a more general rule of these two I think it's important to constantly be out of your depth in the language to progress. Language learning often fails to actually push boundaries and people are left in the little kiddie pool of asking where the library is or ordering beer. They take this as some level of fluency when they're immediately out of their depth trying to hold a non formulaic conversation.

>>21433838
If you are looking for a translation of the Iliad that serves as an accompaniment to the Lattimore translation, then the translations by Anthony Verity, Barry Powell, Caroline Alexander, and Peter Green are all great options. These translations are meant to be more faithful to the original Greek text of the Iliad, while still being accessible to the modern reader. Additionally, you can also consider the translations by Robert Fitzgerald and Richmond Lattimore, which are both highly praised by critics and classicists alike.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: >Ezra Pound (30 October 1885 – 1 November 1972) is widely considered one of the most influential poets of the 20th century; his contributions to modernist poetry were enormous. He was an early champion of a number of avant-garde and modernist poets; developed important channels of intellectual and aesthetic exchange between the United States and Europe; and contributed to important literary movements such as Imagism and Vorticism. His life’s work, The Cantos, remains a signal modernist epic. Its mix of history, politics, and what Pound called “the periplum,” that is a point of view of one in the middle of a journey, have given countless poets permission to develop a range of poetic techniques that capture life in the midst of experience. In an introduction to the Literary Essays of Ezra Pound, T.S. Eliot declared that Pound “is more responsible for the 20th-century revolution in poetry than is any other individual.” Four decades later, Donald Hall reaffirmed in remarks collected in Remembering Poets that “Ezra Pound is the poet who, a thousand times more than any other man, has made modern poetry possible in English.” Pound never sought, nor had, a wide reading audience during his lifetime; his technical innovations and use of unconventional poetic materials often baffled even sympathetic readers. Early in his career, Pound aroused controversy because of his aesthetic views; later, because of his political views, including his support for the Fascist government in Italy. For the greater part of the 20th century, however, Pound devoted his energies to advancing the art of poetry.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>21427606
I'm mostly talking out of my ass because my own story was middling in popularity and swiftly abandoned for unrelated reasons, but the typical figure is at least 1K words a chapter twice or more a week. You want enough to have closure in a single chapter, and the faster the cadence, the more people with short attention spans will be able to enjoy it. That aside the biggest predictor of realisable popularity (i.e. assuming your work is actually worth reading) is the number of words already published – readers know to ignore stories that appear like they will be abandoned.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>21427490
You are going for a punchy writing style.

>might break into pieces like glass if I struck them on the ground.
Simplify this to convey the same idea but with fewer filler words. Also, think if "like glass" is at all necessary here.
>into some sort of cocoon
The word "cocoon" isn't strong enough. I don't care for it. And "some sort of" is definitely bad.

>too tired, too weak
Repetition doesn't fit the style of what you're going for or the rest of the text.
>let alone run deeper into the green inferno of hillside trees
"Let alone" is bad. It's a filler word. Same problem as earlier. The sudden 'poeticism' of "the green inferno of hillside trees" isn't in style with the text. Same as with "cocoon," if you want to paint a specific picture, paint it with a more thorough description or find one word that'll evoke that picture fully. Currently, neither is done.

>Dry leaves going crunch crunch getting louder and louder, closer and closer.
Remove "going." It's filler.
This suggestion will interfere with your creative vision, but I like it more--Try removing the second "louder" and adding an "and" after the comma. This makes the rhythm significantly faster. It also emphasizes "closer and closer," whereas in the original all the alliterating repeating elements of the sentence feel equally flat. It should read:
>>Dry leaves crunch crunch getting louder, and closer and closer.

>my field of vision shrunk like I was looking through a pipe
What is this lol? Feels so out of place.

>from joints to ligaments
Usually, a "to" combines things at the opposite ends of a range. Anatomically, however, joints and ligaments are very near each other. Ligaments surround the joint. A "to" feels misplaced here.

>The god of sleep had an iron grip over me and I had no choice but to surrender to him.
I would rethink this sentence. It doesn't feel punchy enough, not gripping enough. Show the reader how the bones crunch at the tight binding grip of sleep. Make the character surrender, don't just state it to be so.
>But just before I lost consciousness though,
Remove this completely.
>my pinhole of vision
This too.

posts.com:
Henry never listens. His father told him: Henry, you can have the sweets after your dinner if you are good, but you must eat all your greens, okay? Henry? All your greens, yes, Henry?
Henry nodded, of course, with the sweetest face he knew, and his father went off satisfied to have taught his boy a lesson. But Henry had no intention of eating any greens.
While his father mowed the lawn that day, Henry took the bus to the coast and found the first banana boat full of eager hungry immigrants and invited them all home for dinner.
The dining room was crowded wall to wall. Henry's father watched as all the plates of vegetables he had placed on the table were clawed at by a dozen dirty brown hands that scooped them past dry scabby lips and frazzled beards.
Henry stood in the corner with a sour gummy worm swirling around his lips as he sucked the head half of it, its sugar-flecked tail tickling his nose. Mohammad had taken the whole jar of sweets down from the kitchen shelf for him. His father had tried to protest but Mohammad was a fierce man with a single yellow eye and Jamal who stood behind him, glaring and sniffing his fingers endlessly, gave his father such a look that he didn't dare stand in their way.
When his father stepped to the side and watched Mohammad sidle past him and reach to the top shelf for the sweety jar he saw Henry stood in the doorway behind Jamal, smiling sweetly, licking his little red lips, his eyelids twitching like a dreaming dog's leg as he thought about all that sugar those dark hands were bringing to him.
Before his father had been elbowed out of the dining room by the swell of the crowd, he saw little Henry in the corner eating his sweets, his face sticky and red with sugar gunk and his eyes vibrating with a quick desperation; a dozen brown dirty faces hollowed themselves out to draw in plate after plate of broccoli, cabbage, peas and string beans.
In the kitchen Henry's father was wrapped in Jamal's arm who walked him into a corner casually, though there was no hiding the threat in the sharpness of his muddy eyes. You, English, such good greens, said Jamal. Henry no lie: best greens in world. Only £1.99 from Aldi. Wow! Inshallah! Yes, many blessings on you, Papa, you cook good greens. Best!
Now: business, said Jamal, Six sisters mine on next boat, two good curves each; one young, cook well, good goat-stew, no mess. You take, and we sleep here, family. Many wives: good. Henry: he can take a cousin too; she pretty, make him man. You good man, good Papa, strong home, good greens.
Jamal patted Henry's father on the cheek and started yelling at Mohammad who fell through the dining room door, a plate of spinach he had carried flying into the air while the crowd snatched at every airborne leaf.
Henry's father, through the ruckus, for a moment, saw a small white hand through the dining room door raised in the distance, waving, with each white finger glazed with sticky red sugar and chocolate, caramel, marshmallow.

>>21431535
Stream of consciousness requires artistry... more than any other kind of writing approach. That kind of free-associative writing can be good, but it's never strictly because of precisely how free the associations are. I think lots of new writers approach the device in this way, and compete with one another by how quickly they can jump from one thought to another. My advice would be to focus on the form more. SoC isn't an excuse to write poorly. The art of it is in maintaining the free association while not compromising the quality and flow of the prose, both of which have here been fully compromised.

Happy Christlamb in the farm

The Christmas story on the farm began with the three sheep , Leggy, Peggy, and Barbara, preparing to celebrate Christmas. The farm was covered in snow and there was a great atmosphere of excitement and joy in the air.

Santa Claus had arrived at the farm in his sled pulled by reindeer and was distributing gifts to all the animals. Leggy lamb was very excited to receive her gift, while Peggy enjoyed teasing Santa and making jokes. Barbara, on the other hand, was busy preparing a big Christmas dinner for all the animals on the farm.

Meanwhile, the reindeer were busy resting after their long journey through the sky. Rudolph, the red-nosed reindeer, was delighted to be on the farm and was enjoying the fresh air and snow. The other reindeer were also enjoying the opportunity to rest a little before starting their big journey across the whole world to deliver gifts to all the good boys and girls.

Finally, it was time for the Christmas dinner and everyone gathered around the table to enjoy the delicious food prepared by Barbara. There was a great variety of dishes, from eggplant parmesan to vegetables and apple pie. Everyone was very grateful for Barbara's generous hospitality and thanked her for her effort.

After dinner, everyone gathered around the Christmas tree to sing carols and tell Christmas stories. Leggy lamb was delighted to be surrounded by her friends and family, and was very grateful for all the blessings she had received that year. Peggy and Barbara were also very happy and grateful, and promised themselves that they would do their best to make the next Christmas even better.

With a big heart full of love and gratitude, everyone went to bed that night grateful for the wonderful Christmas they had shared together on the farm.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>21432417
To start with, an imaginary friend is a friend who is imaginary. A good analogue for an imaginary person is: a person in your dreams. You know they are a part of you and come from within, but you wouldn't think of them as yourself if you were talking to them; and you can tell they have somewhat separate wills from yours. Imaginary friends aren't much different from these dream people, except you can be aware of them while you are awake. In practice, imaginary friends can provide many benefits. They can provide companionship, motivation, love, understanding, or all these at once. It is up to each person to figure out why they are making an imaginary friend, and what void are they hoping to fill with them.

I also want to be abundantly clear about the following: there is nothing paranormal about this. There is no mysticism or magic here. Imaginary friends aren't demons or entities from another realm, and they certainly can't directly change the world around you. That being said, some of these interpretations can be fun—even useful—to play with, when you consider anything is possible within your inner realm; just as long as you remember that this is the only realm where these things are true.

To summarize the process: our goal is to create a character and get to know them, and play with them in our heads well enough that eventually our subconscious begins taking the lead. In the meantime, we will also be using concentration techniques to help us tune in to our imagined senses, so we can interact with our friend in a richer way within our mind. This will seem odd at first, but it utilizes brain phenomena you have been using since you were born: remembrance, and habit. These are no new ideas, and all it takes is time and the right mindset.

This are the edits I would make. I would recommend reading the essays of Samuel Johnson; the profundity and pithiness which he maintains while explicating a human condition is unparalleled.

Each day another heartache passes by. I stand at the stop on my morning route to work, watching the approaching bus. Will she notice? Will she remember me? I step through it's automatic door. She's there, as always; long brunette hair and a beautiful somber face peering down at her phone. I quickly pass her by and take a seat near the back. This is the second year since I began taking this bus and, aside from the brief occasion here and there, it feels as though we have always been together. Though she doesn't know my name, I know hers; May. I thought that name fitting-- today is the thirty-first of April, and tomorrow-- it will be May. I lean my head on the seat in front of me. The day goes by as usual; she gets off after two stops at K. S. Library on E.M. Street, and I get off the next stop over to work at M. Automotives. After work I take the bus back home, alone.

The time is ten-forty P.M. I pull the journal from under my mattress and set it on the desk. Sixty-seven pages, all addressed to May. I open the journal and begin writing.
"I'm sure you've become quite bored if you've made it this far. The good news is that this will be the last entry. I want to speak with you tomorrow, but, as usual, I am afraid. It dawns on me just how creepy I was, how disgusting I have been observing you in this one-sided relationship. Tomorrow will be my lowest point yet, perhaps, but also my highest. Will it hurt you? I tried to think of any other way. I didn't want to become what I am now. Every day hurts me, every moment that I am alone sends me into conniptions of pain and sorrow. I'm being melodramatic, I suppose. The truth is that I know what I'm doing now and what I am soon to do is inexcusable. I cannot escape the simple fact that I am alone for no other reason than this: that I am a monster. You did well to avoid me, as everyone else has. Even now, in this very written letter, I demonstrate how wrong I am."

"So many times I resolved to ask your name, to introduce myself; each time I simply passed you by. I always knew that if we were to have a relationship, even a simple friendship, you would sense my inner wrongness and turn away in disgust. I don't blame you. This letter is proof enough that as dignified as I attempt to appear, I am little more than a stalker. But even if you were to put up with me, I understand that there is a problem more fundamental to my being. I could never make you happy. I wouldn't be able to bear slowly corrupting your innocent joy with my sadistic melancholy. This is why I have resolved to who I am; A creep. A stalker. A monster. I loved you, May."

I sit at the bus stop, my journal peeking out from the small bag at my side. I feel sick. My heart races. I try to calm my breath to no avail. I look at my watch: Seven-fifteen. She will see me soon. Time crawls slowly forwards. On the distant hill I see the bus in its approach; it will arrive in approximately two minutes. Regret. I toss the bag into the bin and stand and creep down the sidewalk, steadying my trembling arms. Will she notice? Will she remember me? I step towards the bus, and another heartache takes a hold of me.

>>21434433
You're trying too hard. I don't mean in terms of effort, but rather you're trying to mimic what good writing looks like rather than actually embodying it. That's why it's shit or cringe, whatever word you want to use.

>For, I could not fathom how to balance descriptions,
This is retarded. Stop writing like this

>Every attempt was choppy, awkward, stilted -- i.e. words completely lacking in the elements that make a story flow and enjoyable to read.
Could any of you with success in writing stories provide any tips on ways that I can improve?

You're just beginning. The last thing you need to consciously worry about is the flow or the elements, or whatever the fuck. You're a beginner. Play around with the box. Turn it around. Open it and see what's inside. When you're good enough to understand a story, not at an intellectual level, but an innate level, then you can start going outside and tinkering with the mechanics. But you aren't even at first base. So what's my advice? Write a short novel, sixty thousand words, with zero fucks about how someone else is going to see it. Feel the writing process out. You're not going to write anything worth shit for a couple years. A lot of people here ask stupid questions like, "how do you write dialogue?" If you have to fucking ask, writing isn't for you. After you've written 100,000 words (just throwing shit out there) and you come back having introduced yourself to it, then you can ask, "what are some ways I can improve my flow?"

>>21434433
>lone individual
>ruined and damaged
First go through and edit out redundancy.
>he fought back tears
Same with any common phrases. These are usually not offensive, but are missed opportunities for something stronger.
>As he sat atop the ... as he fought back tears...
Generally just write things in chronological order. Only describe things as simultaneous when you need it for things to make sense. Here you've jumbled up several actions and repeated 'as' which sounds awkward.

You probably need more buildup for a scene with any kind of weight or horror or danger. It's too brief. Without knowing characters first, the reader is not invested in the story.

You might want to try the pulp fiction formula of writing in action-reaction units.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>21430812
You're an ESTP. It stands for Extroverted Sensing Thinking Perceiver. When it's a J at the end, you're a "Judger," but all that denotes is whether your dominant function is a perceptive function, like Sensing (Si)(Se), or Intuition (Ni)(Ne), versus having a judgement function dominant, i.e., Thinking or Feeling. Since you're a dominant Extroverted Sensor, that gives the ES-P. Since you prefer Thinking (Ti)(Te), over Feeling (Fi)(Fe), you get a T. Hence, ESTP. Hope that helps.

No, problem. Merry Christmas! You should try it seriously, for your own benefit, but a word of caution - once you understand this system it becomes impossible not to see. People's functions start leaping out at you all the time, and sometimes you'll recognize correlation between persons you wouldn't necessarily want mentally associated, and it can have emotional effect. >>21429461
Yes, they simply don't take the time to actually understand the core concepts. Jung would be excited. Personality Types was a major part of his work, yet most of it was relegated to the past, and he was largely eclipsed by Freud in mainstream psychology. It's only with advanced development of his theories that the correlations to modern neurology will become fully clear. Jung was always interested in the relationship of psychology to the hard sciences. There are correlations which will inevitably become apparent, but which may never have without the work of Jungian typists, and there are even specialized psychologists who legitimately apply treatment under consideration of a Myers-Briggs type. I find it fascinating and fun. There just isn't any value in dismissal without knowledge.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>21424683
His misanthropy probably isn’t compelling to you because it’s not just outright misanthropy, searching for ugliness what to weaponize hatred with. It’s more that ugliness constantly presents itself to him which he describes and diagnoses appropriately. His writing is rambling at points certainly but I think it has a real driving flow to it, so it never becomes boring or impenetrable. Bolaño is a decent comparison, in that there’s a humor to his writing which does not undercut the real emotional weight—although bolaño is much more stylistically austere and fat less negative.
Mainly I just like novels with a slightly ironic wit to them in which characters philosophize about the world. It’s important to note that even tho the main character of journey is himself, it’s clearly a representation of himself that he’s equally as critical of.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>21424790
This is only partly true. Celine referred to himself solely as a "stylist" in the radio interviews to deflect from the reputation he had built following the war. He was beloved by a select of French writers and politically-ignorant Americans, but despised by the establishment. Hence he tried to repurpose his work as an exercise in style and nothing more. But the style serves a purpose, it isn't l'art pour l'art, but a style necessary to communicate disgust toward the world that fell apart before his eyes. This is why he favored Dostoyevsky, Shakespeare, Conrad... writers who confronted the darker side of the human spirit. The language reflects this and not itself.

The world of La Belle Epoque was gone, and with it the language had to go to, but why this is is the question Celine asks. Just look at the war, the grotesque details of abortion, the hatred of the mechanical Soviet state in the letters, the love/hate of Germany, the medievalism... to understand this is much too difficult for his francophone sycophants and the idiot right-wing people whom he himself despised. You cannot reproduce Celine - not in style nor in narration nor in perspective - unless you yourself have eyes that have seen horrors comparable to his.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>21425275
Yes, but as I said, his stylistic intent became obscured by his own clever/dismissive attitude toward the reporters who were mostly interested in political melodrama. He mentioned somewhere, maybe to Milton Hindus, that slang is the language of hatred. The worker hates his boss so he invents his own lingo, his own form of verbal disgust. Céline transformed this into his protest against the cruelties of human nature. But now even the most respected Céliniens in France act as if he was a kind of language-theorist or a stylist somewhat akin to Nabokov or Updike. It’s always the same, you talk to a Frenchman about Céline and they’ll have to tell you… “well, the politics, sure I don’t agree… but what amazing language! L’argot!” Okay, but they have nothing deeper to say, since either they are too afraid to praise the substance in his style or too stupid to realize it exists.

The Céline popularity transformed a lot. Voyage was of course major news in its day, beloved by some (mostly rebellious leftish types) and hated by Montherlant and the like, who considered it too ephemeral. Now nobody reads Montherlant, and his would-be reactionary fans read Céline! But after the war it all fell apart and he became a dirty name in France. Only the fascists and weirdos wanted anything to do with him (not a bad thing of course!). The “rehabilitation” of a writer is different in France, as the idea of greatness still exists there, unlike in the US of A. By the 60s, just after he had died and successfully passed off his novels as stylistic exercises, all the big names began to praise him as a genius. You have that idiot Philippe Sollers, who will defend Céline’s reputation to the end, “our Joyce” or something to that effect… now yes, he is everywhere, from Israel to Timbuktu to Singapore everyone thinks they’re a little Céline. You go to a bookshop in Paris and there are fresh editions of Céline full of comic book illustrations, Céline-themed dildos, Célinien mechanical keyboards that’ll glow beneath your tranny cat ears as you play the Céline Simulator 1936, the latest in antisemitic writing games… a circus, and the only way out of it is to read between his lines.

I will say the one place Céline is thankfully neglected is the USA. I recently read that stupid bitch Alice Kaplan talk about how she can barely read him anymore, that she only likes how he exposed colonialism in Africa, that he is too much. Good! Good riddance! Americans, with the exception amusingly enough of Bukowski, never really understood Céline for what he was. The same goes for Proust, who is probably the writer who is, spiritually, the closest to what Céline was saying

Not that anon, but what do you think it was that made him "rehabilitation-compatible"? Writers have been damnatio memoriaed for much lesser slights. And most other collaborationist writers are to my knowledge "off limits" even to this day, like Rebatet, Drieu La Rochelle, or Brasillach.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>21425794
Well, a mixture of his "I am simply a stylist" statements and the generally rebellious nature of his work. He is part of the old European tradition of literature, one that dates back to Rabelais in France (and even earlier if we look at the medieval chroniclers he read late in life)... but he is distinctively apart from the classical, mannerly, pretty writers that were in vogue in the early 1900s. As such a lot of modern artists, like Dubuffet, and leftish types, like Sartre and Debord, came to love his spirit, whereas I do not think Brasillach's writing really lends itself to such a thing. Brasillach is not as good as Celine... that is one thing you have to understand. Celine is at the level of Dante in terms of what he can evoke with words, how it flows, the drama he can build in a single sentence, the severity of his statements. So naturally it would have been hard to ignore him, even without the non-fascists who came to like him. Celine was not a fascist himself, but that is another story...

France, as I've said, has a reverence for greatness in a way that is unheard of in America and I assume the UK. To a Frenchman, literature is number one, and you can get away with a great deal of things as a writer... countless French writers were pederasts who went to Algeria to have their way with the local boys, but their names adorn the streets of Paris. Yet Americans won't read Lolita simply because it is ABOUT something they find disturbing. So in general, one has to do a lot to really lose out on immortality if one is a great writer in French.

Rebatet is an interesting case. I am not French (though I have lived there) nor am I that familiar with all the details of his life/work. I imagine it has something to do with his novel being published AFTER the war, whereas we can all make the excuse that Voyage came "before Celine lost his mind" as the imbeciles love to say.

>>21426843
I have done nothing but praise Celine. His neglect in the USA is positive, as American literary culture is completely devoid of substance these days. We do not need the frauds to start their little assessments of Celine, the genderqueer interpretations of Bardamu and Robinson! My friend, I rank Celine as a brother of Dante, as I said in a previous post (not the one you replied to). I have nothing but positive things to say about Celine, even/especially regarding Bagatelles etc. where his real philosophy is elucidated.

He was the greatest stylist of French literature period, but as I've explained innumerable times, for reasons much deeper than people realize. The comparisons with Joyce that the French make are so faulty, as if they need their own Ulysses to feel intellectual. Joyce gets lost in formal tricks and obscures the emotions of his characters (except in chapter 3 and the Molly monologue)... but Celine never fell for this. What the two were saying is essentially dissimilar... Celine is closest to Proust in his pessimism toward "the good life," only instead of attacking the aristocrats and the nouveau riche he tore down the dignity of war and the mechanistic world that has entirely destroyed the human spirit. Joyce tried to find odd beauty in the everyday (still a great writer and genius!) and as such ignores the greater issues that Celine addressed...

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>21428840
I've read him in both English and French. As you know, his style changed at various points. Journey/Voyage being the most "traditional" of his works. The Marks translation turned him into a disgruntled Victorian, but Ralph Mannheim captures a lot of his imagery without much of the flow. I will say that Mannheim's translations of the WW2 trilogy do indeed have the "hateful whispering" that you get from late Celine in French, but naturally some things were changed. The essence of Celine (as he himself said) was emotion via distortion, you have to distort with words to achieve the real feeling. Gide said something to the effect of "Celine is not reality, but the residue of reality." If so, then yes, it works with Mannheim. My Italian friends have praised his translation into that language, though I have heard Germans complain that he doesn't work well in Deutsch.

That anonymous translation of Bagatelles is quite interesting - it has some of the frenzied hate of the original, but a lot of the puns don't work in English, of course. Henry Miller (an optimistic Celine knock-off who is not really worth reading) actually imitated some of his style quite well in English. Tropic of Cancer is all over the place, some chapters like Proust, others like Dos Passos, others like Celine, others like Joyce, others like Nietzsche... but somehow he placed some of Journey's style in English by 1934 or whenever. But he lacked Celine's great conception of the world and so he couldn't really go anywhere with his talent...

>>21429460
All of Céline is great, but personally speaking I like Journey the best. It is the most grand of his works, his epic, the adventure gone wrong! Swift’s cynicism upgraded with Dostoyevsky’s deep investigations of the soul. But every era has its own merits. The German novels are the iconic Céline, the really fed-up Céline who is ready to insult every last man on earth for his gluttony. They are the funniest of his works, and I know many who find them to be the peak of his style (I somewhat agree with this). The pamphlets are also essential reading if you know French or want to try the quite good English rendition of Bagatelles. The whole Jew hate thing is unimportant, what matters is the message: the critiques of Cézanne, the love of dance, the standardization of life… his whole philosophy comes to being there, but it has been obscured by the sensitive types who menstruate whenever someone says anything about the Jews. And besides, the pamphlets themselves are not these hysterical rants of genocide-advocacy… the average /pol/ user is far more brutal than Céline in this regard (but with none of his elegant aggression!). If you know/are learning French, his interviews are also essential. He speaks with a great musical sense and comedic brilliance… they are like his later novels, full of cynicism yet simultaneously you find the doctor, the vegetarian, the mystic, the defeated humanist… in short, Céline.

Don’t expect a translation of his “new” work into English anytime soon. New Directions have milked Céline only thanks to Laughlin having supported/published him back in the day. I can’t imagine the smaller presses wanting anything to do with him. I could be wrong of course… but unlike Pound, Céline isn’t exactly iconic in American literature. He influenced a lot of people, but not in a way you can really dissect in a $200,000 “literature” undergrad… so who is going to read him besides us? They’d rather publish the latest Ashbery clones and homoerotic auto fiction than Céline. And in an age of Bolaño (and new Latin American fiction in general) and the countless Japanese translations, the idea of a French author just isn’t exotic enough to appeal to the intelligentsia who crave to prove their worldliness by the books they pose next to their matcha lattes. Not that there is a problem with the Latin Americans or Japanese, but just take a look at what the trendsters are reading in translation… all while neglecting some of the best writers because of political reasons… a complete circus

>>21429585

I hope our little chat has brought Céline’s richness to the attention of the other worthy readers here (one can only hope they’ll stop caring about Ottessa Moshfegh’s merit and the Asian “how to wear tweed” child and invest their time in the real stuff).

posts.com: In the artificial valley bed of concrete and rocks made explicitly as a storm drain out behind the apartment complex, there were a series of heavily tarred wooden beams lain flat as brace against the encroaching earth ready to swallow again the false triumph of man. Climbing this four yard high wall of riveted shipwood, filled with rusted tacks and nails, burrowing like metal worms in the surface, I built a memory. This memory was one of youthful innocence, of imagined adventures and journeys, and of loneliness. Though I was in a sprawling metropolis, I was unambiguously alone. No other children played in this apartment complex which was divided into four parts including a very exclusive pool that became as good as my own for at least five summers, and none of my memories contain any youths but those I would occasionally invite from school. In my loneliness, I did not create imaginary friends, but instead adventures, whole journeys across this little patch, this green kingdom, this false forest in the booming city. I fondly look back at the moment climbing this wall, its nacreous black globs of tar under my fingers, the bright green crest of grass at the top that was the goal, the hooks and splinters that were foes of my poor pants and shirt, they who sought to arrest my ascent. The smell of the summer heat softened tar burns my nose still to this day.

posts.com: Pain, embarrassment, shame and anger. These were my emotions as I helped myself up from the cold hard ground. I turned to see the two girls. Maybe they didn’t see? Maybe they planted that basket there as a friendly prank that we could all laugh about together over drinks. Maybe they thought my ability to fall over was really cool and sexy? Unfortunately for me, the girls reacted exactly as one would expect. Laughter and pity. I tried to play it cool. “Haha. Yeah that was wacky and im not a virgin”. They wouldn’t listen. Their cackles grew to a manic swell. The lights dimmed. Crows screeched and lightning struck the earth like a drum- a hellish marching beat towards an existence of sheer pain. Forever doomed to virgin walk the earth at slightly above average pace. Tripping on the stairs at work because I tried to step 3 steps in one stride instead of the usual 2. Wiping the tears away. Not because I hurt myself on the stairs, but because I didn’t break my record of 2 steps in one stride.

posts.com: I remember one time I was going through the self checkout at the supermarket and I accidentally forgot to scan a few items. By the time I realized my mistake- one of the staff members had chased me into the carpark and out to my car. They kept slamming the car door shut when I would try to put my groceries in- all the while shouting “No, no, no, no”. I said to the lady I said “ Hey! Just what the heck are you doing touching my car? This is my private property. I bought this car when the Lehman Brothers crash happened in 08’ and I paid it off fair and square. Do you need to see my loan statement just so I can prove it to you? I lost that statement years ago- how the heck would I get another one while we’re out here in this car park?”. Stumped- she clearly had no answer to my question. Assuming I had done my part in defusing the situation- I resumed loading my groceries into my purple Hyundai Getz. She started shouting again. “You need to pay for those!” she cried. I said “Lady, I just told you I bought and paid for this car fair and square back in 2008 when the Lehman Brothers crash happened. It’s my private property, has nothing to do with you and frankly even if we were friends- I’m not looking to sell right now. Now if you don’t take a step back- I’ll have no choice but to use my mace on you”. I pulled out my medieval flail and entered defense position 3. I’d been taking self defense classes from my disabled neighbour. He taught me to never let my guard down and to always check his dad's cabinets for oreos. The lady shouted again. “I don’t care about your car! It’s the groceries…”. I said “Lady if you don’t care about my car then why don’t you make like the wind and fuck off already. This car ain’t for sale”. I launched my mace at her head. The spiked ball slammed into her face and made an incredible impact on her skull. She instantly surrendered by going limp and dropping to the floor...

Blood began to pool where she lay. I knelt down to see the regret on her face. Her mouth was wide open and her face was completely motionless. She wasn't blinking, all I could see was 2 lifeless pupils. 2 lifeless pupils that were pointed towards my aftermarket exhaust pipe that I spent months saving for. “I gotta hand it to you lady- you’re persistent. You don’t give up. And when you set your mind on something- you pursue it to the very end. I like that. It takes balls to be that stubborn- but god dammit it’s the only true way to get what you want in this crazy fucking world”. I took a depleted drag from my cigarette, dropped it to the ground and stomped it out in one smooth motion. I reached into my pocket, pulled out my car keys and held them out in my hand. The sun was setting. The orange light reflected off of the keys and shimmered in my hand like a diamond in the rough. I loosened my grip- and the keys fell to the earth. The metal of the keys bounced against the hard concrete ground. It was then my stride took flight and I began to walk away. The sun is setting before me- as if to say “that’ll do”. I walk into the horizon and slowly I disappear- all while ‘The Sound Of Silence’ slowly fades in- and the credits roll.

As she walked up to the shelf directly behind me she stopped for a moment and glanced towards me, as if appraising this odd creature sitting there. I ignored her as I ignore all women. What came next is still inexplicable to me. In one smooth motion she tucks her hair behind her ear, bends over and slightly swivels her body so that her bottom is directly aligned with the side of my head, not even a full ten centimeters away. Seeing that wonderful heart shaped peach even more accentuated by those dark pants so close to me was a very pleasant surprise at first. But then it hit me. The smell. The stench. Her bottom half had a truly rank, powerful stink to it and I was shocked, I had never experienced anything like it before, how can such a beautiful girl carry this smell with her? I always thought they clean themselves very thoroughly. In the first moment I was taken aback but in the second I had to force myself not to inhale deeply because I couldn’t get enough of it. I loved her stink. My nethers were throbbing and I feared that she might hear the sound of my flesh pulsing and rubbing against the fabric of my clothes. I quickly checked the room, which was empty, and tried to guess if there were any cameras set up in a library, I even thought that perhaps getting kicked out of university and maybe even getting a minor conviction might not be so bad, I was still young after all. I had never gotten so close to…well, you know. Finally, after what seemed like an eternity both pleasurable and torturous, pleasurable for my eyes and nose and torturous for the inability to indulge, she picked her book, stood straight again and danced off, leaving me aching and yearning for her dark smell. I had to remain sitting down for a few minutes until I was finally able to get up and walk off to clear my thoughts. I have never seen her again and I have never forgotten her nor her smell.

>>21433594
In the summer of 2010, I was staring down the tail-end of a year in Afghanistan. Our company was holding perimeter for the very last "clearing op" we'd have to do before rotating home. At that point I was filling in as a driver of a Stryker for a guy who'd gotten hurt in an IED blast and rotated home. It was dusk and night was falling; we had every one of our company's trucks picketing the perimeter around a town called Shah Wali Kot, where months later there'd be a major offensive. Since the trucks were parked, I was hanging out the rear hatch with my rifle, pulling security, as pops of gunfire echoed throughout the dusty caldera in which the town sat.

I felt both alert and completely at peace — existing purely in that moment — unafraid and ready to do violence. As I was scanning the horizon, listening to the sounds of combat, I saw a plane approaching. It came on station, circled, then nosed down into an almost unbelievably steep dive. In the dimming light and against the last pastel vestiges of sunset came belching an unbroken stream of incendiary rounds from the nose of the plane, appearing as one solid, unbroken beam of light. The sound that followed, seconds after, set my ears to ringing. The plane climbed steeply, came back on station. As night fell, I watched four or five more sallies from the untouchable plane, and felt very, very glad that it was on our side.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Each day another heartache passes by. I stand at the stop on my morning route to work, watching the approaching bus. Will she notice? Will she remember me? I step through it's automatic door. She's there, as always; long brunette hair and a beautiful somber face peering down at her phone. I quickly pass her by and take a seat near the back. This is the second year since I began taking this bus and, aside from the brief occasion here and there, it feels as though we have always been together. Though she doesn't know my name, I know hers; May. I thought that name fitting-- today is the thirty-first of April, and tomorrow-- it will be May. I lean my head on the seat in front of me. The day goes by as usual; she gets off after two stops at K. S. Library on E.M. Street, and I get off the next stop over to work at M. Automotives. After work I take the bus back home, alone.

The time is ten-forty P.M. I pull the journal from under my mattress and set it on the desk. Sixty-seven pages, all addressed to May. I begin writing.
"I'm sure you've become quite bored if you've made it this far. The good news is that this will be the last entry. I want to speak with you tomorrow, but, as usual, I am afraid. It dawns on me just how creepy I was, how disgusting I have been observing you in this one-sided relationship. Tomorrow will be my lowest point yet, perhaps, but also my highest. Will it hurt you? I tried to think of any other way. I didn't want to become what I am now. Every day hurts me, every moment that I am alone throws me into painful conniptions. I'm being melodramatic, I suppose. The truth is that I know what I'm doing now and what I am soon to do is inexcusable. I cannot escape the simple fact that I am alone for no other reason than this: that I am a monster. You did well to avoid me, as everyone else has. Even now, in this very written letter, I demonstrate how wrong I am."

"So many times I resolved to ask your name, to introduce myself; each time I simply passed you by. I always knew that even if we were to have a simple friendship, you would sense my inner wrongness and turn away in disgust. I don't blame you. This letter is proof enough that as dignified as I attempt to appear, I am little more than a stalker. But even if you were to put up with me, I understand that there is a problem more fundamental to my being. I could never make you happy. I wouldn't be able to bear slowly corrupting your innocent joy with my sadistic melancholy. This is why I have resolved to acknowledge what I am; A creep. A stalker. A monster. I loved you, May."

I sit at the bus stop, my journal peeking out from the small bag at my side. I feel sick. My heart races. I try to calm my shaking breath to no avail. I look at my watch: Seven-fifteen; she will see me soon. Time crawls slowly forwards. On the distant hill I see the bus in its approach; it will arrive in approximately two minutes. Regret. I toss the bag into the bin and creep down the sidewalk, steadying my trembling arms. Will she notice? Will she remember me? I step towards the bus, and another heartache grips me.

The driver pulls the brakes and we come to a sudden stop; A loud thud shakes the bus. I look up from my phone. Passengers are looking about in confused and curious manners. "Someone got hit!" one man shouts. We are instructed not to leave until the police arrive. After some time the ordeal is over and we continue on our route. I stare at my phone, mindlessly scrolling through pages I never read, and wonder who the dead man was.

>Just as protagonist is about to lose his mind and do something rash, the puppet turns its head toward the back of the store where a curtain covers a small store room. posts.com:
>>21429737
Arguably my favorite book. It’s hard to put into words but getting a first hand account of how one of the great artistic presence saw art and life. I find the letters inseparable from the artwork. Vincent was a cankerous oddball that was poor socially so he pours his heart out to his brother and benefactor who always believed in him. It manages to be sad and inspiring at the same time. On one hand you have the starving artist who would not compromise his vision and sellout commercially to make money; his brother always believing in him and supporting him financially; the heartbreaks and breakdowns that Vincent suffered; his early death not knowing success or fame; his brother not giving up after his death and pushing his artwork; his brother’s death 6 months after Vincent’s with neither succeeding. On the other hand Vincent had some profound thoughts and saw the world in a beautiful way. He reminds me of a peasant savant. It is such a unique look through the lens of a great artist. I’ve probably read it 5 or 6 times and it’s worthwhile every time. One day I’ll get the complete set though it is a bit pricey. I like the Penguin edition because it has a little blurb or summary before every letter explaining various situations and circumstances. I strongly recommend trying it out. Worst possibility is you don’t like it and drop it. It is one of my favorite books and I wish I could share it with others

For anyone who asks how:
seven-eight years ago, I took five English classes in college and I had to read five novels a week. I had to train myself to read faster while still retaining understanding of the literature. I found I could read those books (200-300 pages typically) in about 4-6 hours. There are variables in here too. I annotate while I read, which I think sharpened my reading speed. I've retained that skill ever since. I average about 50 pages an hour

Other variables include prose style and book length. A spare style like Hammett's or Cain's or, I swear, McCarthy's, made those ones breezier reading. Stuff like Delillo, the film criticism I read, more academic stuff, was headier, harder, slower reading.

yes, something like Etruscans not having have voiced /g/ in their phonetic repertoire and its variants, so old Greek gamma for them came to represent unvoiced /k/
Latins adopted it, but they like Greeks perceived the difference between /k/ and /g/, so eventually they adapted their own alphabet by adding a little leg to letter C to distinguish the two sounds, even though being native before this reform they knew when symbol "C" sounded like /k/ and when it sounded like /g/

ΥΓΙΑ

The first character in line 1 can't be a nu, so it must be an upsilon. The last character in line 2 is definitely a sigma. They used to write them just like c's sometimes. The first character in line one looks like a digamma, but it could be a damaged epsilon.

The digamma is used even today in Greek counting. Granted, it appears only in a few modern editions of classical texts to indicate chapter 6. Most editions use Roman numerals, not Greek nor Arabic. Digamma is a consonant that makes a wuh sound (and maybe further complicated stuff, which we don't want to get into here), so there's no way that wlaa makes sense as a word, but it could potentially, I'm not very familiar with Greek counting, be a number: 6+30+1+1 (38). Mary being an olive tree with that digamma actually being an epsilon makes more sense to me. We could go in the weeds a little deeper, especially since you think Mary refers to Jesus' mother, but I'm pretty sure it's the olive tree thing.
I'm interested in buying rather old things. I almost bid on a lot containing a couple Ethiopian texts and some metal objects this week. I never bid, and it went out of my price range. All the people that I know from university hate privately held antiquities and such, meaning they won't give advice. I'm very much of the opposite position. Authenticity is tough to verify. Even the best auction houses have sold fakes, and most don’t offer much of a provenance. It’s all about visual inspection and context. Someone who sells metal detector finds and who lives near a site is probably selling genuine artifacts. From Catullus 36:
> Nunc, ō caeruleō creāta pontō,
> quae sanctum Īdalium Ūriōsque apertōs
> quaeque Ancōna Cnidumque harundinōsam
> colis, quaeque Amathunta, quaeque Golgōs,
> quaeque Durrachium Hadriae tabernam,
> acceptum face redditumque vōtum,
> sī nōn illepidum neque invenustum est.

Everyone translates the beginning to something like
> Now, o [Venus],
> who haunts [list of places]
But there's no verb corresponding to haunting in the original, in fact there's no verb at all. None of the commentaries I found even mention an implicit verb in this sentence.
Is this kind of address to gods so common that it's not even worth picking apart? Does someone know any other examples from other authors in the same format (i.e., the god or pronoun in the nominative, and a list of places in the accusative, without any verb)?

>>21432740
If you see a bunch of 的, 了, 這, 個, 你, 就, 沒, 他, 那, 們, 嗎, 吧 it's modern. If you see a bunch of 矣, 曰, 則, 乃, 乎, 哉, 焉 or sentence-final 也, it's probably Classical. It's a little harder for a layman to tell something is definitely classical than to tell it's definitely modern, because modern Chinese borrows a lot from Classical, much like the Romance languages borrow a lot from Latin.

>>21433777
Nta, but you should know that *early* pre-classical Chinese does not use 矣 or 也. Its nominal sentences use 維 / 唯 / 惟 as a positive copula and 非 as a negative one.

There's quite a bit of variation in literary Chinese. "Classical Chinese" as a language typically refers to the literary language used in texts from the 5th to 3rd century BC (the essential educational assets of subsequent centuries and millennia were created during this period, hence "classical").
To get a feeling for just how much the literary language generally varies, I'll quote: https://hxwd.org/concept.html?uuid=uuid-418ea48e-b91f-4303-8076-be3ca87f9da5 (I highly recommend using this site, btw)
>The final particle yě 也 is interpreted by some as a sentence-final copula, but it is properly regarded as a sentential particle marking non-narrative modes of predication.
>The standard copula in Warring States Chinese is wéi 為, which tends to have human subjects and is by no means as common in Chinese as the copula is in Western languages.
>Yuē 曰 is current as a copula in listings of items and the like.
>Yún 云 is a rare archaising copula in ZUO.
>Zé 則 is copula-like after contrastive subjects.
>Nǎi 乃 is copula-like and contrastive and stresses that the subject is none other than the predicate.
>Dāng 當 "act as, fulfill the function of" is copula-like, but there is only a slight degree of grammaticalisation in the direction of a copula.
>Wèi 謂 "be counted as, count as" sometimes moves in the direction of copula-like uses.
>Shì 是 is a resumptive demonstrative pronoun which on very rare occasions can come to function very much as a copula.
>Zhòng 中 has some copula-like uses in GUAN, when the word means "amount to, cost" and sometimes even stands before ordinary nominal predicates.
>Yǐ 以 "as a SUBJECT" functions quite regularly as a subordinate copula in classical Chinese.
And that's just something as basic as copula (not to mention, only a few ones at that). Also, keep in mind these characters all have dozens of different context-dependent definitions too.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>21431909
Yes, he is one of the few philosophers where this is possible. There's at least a few possible reasons for this. One is that, despite his purported aristocratic tendencies, his thought is rooted in very surface-level common-sense rebuttals of previous philosophical ideas (which had sophisticated reasoning backing them), which are generally the first to come to mind to any layperson when they are presented with these kinds of ideas (hence why Nietzsche catches on well with so many who are either first entering philosophy, or who just lack intellectual sophistication in general). In this sense, Nietzsche's philosophy is uniquely plebeian and unsophisticated. It gains most of its sophistication through his elegant prose and his ability to make simplistic thoughts seem deeper than they are. His unique perspective on psychology is one of the only worthwhile aspects of his thought.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>21431909
Ignore those saying no; the nature of his polemics allows one to grasp the argument central to his work without a knowledge of those he attacks (Plato, Kant, Schopenhauer, etc.). I will say though that, upon reading his works before any other philosophers, you will certainly have a view of previous philosophers that lacks nuance. Beyond Good and Evil was one of the first philosophical works I read after a few sparse readings of Plato and Aristotle and the first chapter left me with an ignorant disavowal of Kant and Spinoza that took a few months of reading the philosophical "canon" to get over. Essentially, yes, you can start with Nietzsche and it is a rewarding experience that will get you interested in philosophy, but be sure to go back and do the proper readings after you read some of his works. I can guarantee you that you will approach Nietzsche differently after doing so.

I just can't philosophically understand the "there is nothing after death" claim. I have never seen a sensible argument for it. The only arguments that I have seen are "it just makes sense" or "the simplest solution; what you see is what you get," but that's never the case with our reality, so those arguments both go out the window.

It makes more sense to most people that a man created the world, but it turns out the world came from a 13 billion year old explosion which created several forces of nature which then changed into other forces, and then random functions of nature randomly created matter and anti-matter, and made more matter than anti-matter despite the ratio being unexplainable to this day. My point being, things aren't simple, ever.

So it's stupid to say "the simplest solution is correct." Math and physics are not simple at all. Not even if you boil it down, it's still not simple, because it could always be simpler than it is, it could have been much simpler in fact, than that.

The only other arguments I've seen are ad hominem and "there's nothing after death because, there just isn't, okay?" Those arguments are even worse, and clearly it's some kind of emotional cope from people who are afraid of hell or reincarnation. They have convinced themselves to stubbornly believe there is nothing after death because they are very afraid that they might have to continue existing forever... which scares them greatly, they want to escape but they can't. An even stupider version of their argument is "it will be just like it was before you were born! *smirks like a smartass*"

Anyway, from my own perspective as a human, before I was born, I was born. So, when I die it means I will be born again?

I simply haven't seen an intelligent argument in favor of "death is the end." I don't know what death is, it could be good, or it could be bad, or it could be neutral, but I don't think it's "the end."

Of course you need positive evidence. But negative evidence is a special kind of positive evidence, a kind which does not prove anything specific, but eliminates impossibilities and therefore actually gives us a broader kind of positive knowledge about mere possibilities vs impossibilities.

>>21433933
Joel Oppenheimer!
He was a poet who was superficially associated with Black Mountain and New York School, but was really in a league of his own. His form was impeccable, despite being more conservative than his contemporaries. He's very fond of vulgar language, due to writing out of the sexual liberation, which normally I'm not a fan of, but he is not just gratuitously profane. Oppenheimer's real thesis was that sex is the only primal instinct which humans have retained since the industrial revolution, and that the sexual liberation movement actually did more to harm this than help this. Really interesting stuff. The Woman Poems is one of the greatest poetry volumes I've ever read.
